awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Innovative Latent Energy Exchanger for Effective Recovery of Industrial Wet Exhausts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to save water and energy across a wide spectrum of industrial and commercial applications (i.e. boilers, baking ovens, furnaces, proofers, HVAC systems) that emit wet exhaust into the environment. For example, the U.S. bread baking market segment alone may save over 50 million therms of energy and over 400 million gallons of water annually with the proposed technology.  The proposed project will create a new class of high-efficient and cost-effective equipment for energy recovery and energy efficiency improvement.

This SBIR Phase I project develops a unique energy transfer concept for high-efficient and cost-effective phase-change energy conversion. State-of-the-art heat exchange processes use linear heat transfer mechanisms. In contrast, the proposed approach accounts for the non-linear heat distribution during the condensation process. As a result, the mass of partially condensed mixture changes along the flow channel, and thus causes a corresponding change in local dew point. This approach defines a design configuration for efficient capture and maximal recovery of latent energy from the wet gas flow. The proposed concept successfully exploits the thermo-fluid advantages of spiral channels and thermosiphons. The project will resolve key technological gaps and address issues including condensation sustainability at variable channel geometry and changing flow parameters, and the thermosiphon’s optimal performance at unconventional conditions. The non-linear phase-change heat transfer mechanisms will be defined and simulated, followed by a sensitivity analysis and design optimization of the channel geometry and thermosiphons array for subsequent prototype design and performance demonstration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the NSF SBIR Phase I project titled "Innovative Latent Energy Exchanger for Effective Recovery of Industrial Wet Exhausts," Smart Heat Corporation (SHC) and the project team achieved significant advancements with the development of the Poly-Latent Energy eXchanger (PLEX). This innovative device, designed for efficient and cost-effective recovery of energy and water from industrial wet exhausts, addresses the substantial loss of latent heat commonly observed in these systems. Traditional systems primarily recover sensible heat and overlook the significant energy encapsulated as latent heat in water vapor. The PLEX device utilizes a novel multi-stage heat transfer process to condense this vapor, recovering up to 95% of latent heat and substantially reducing waste heat, while improving overall energy efficiency.

During the project, SHC obtained a general concept patent titled "Apparatus and Method for Latent Energy Exchange," reflecting the innovative nature of the PLEX design. The team also published their findings in the proceedings of the 21st International Heat Pipe Conference (IHPC) and the 15th International Heat Pipe Symposium (IHPS), contributing significantly to the body of knowledge in this field. Furthermore, extensive outreach efforts were made to industry, government agencies, and potential customers, which led to the development of key industry and manufacturing partnerships. These efforts led to the identification of specific industrial applications where the PLEX prototype could be effectively demonstrated. This strategic alignment with industry partners validated the technology and set the stage for future commercial deployments.

The broader impacts of the PLEX are multifaceted, spanning energy savings, environmental sustainability, and advancements in education and workforce development. By dramatically reducing the energy required for heating and drying processes across various industries, such as food processing and chemical manufacturing, the PLEX contributes to significant operating cost reductions and a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions. This promotes a sustainable approach to industrial energy use and aligns with global efforts to reduce environmental impact. The project also provided educational opportunities and workforce development through collaborations with educational institutions, which afforded students practical, hands-on experience in cutting-edge technology development and engineering design. These initiatives, particularly focused on inclusivity and diversity, are vital for cultivating a skilled workforce capable of advancing future technological innovations.

In conclusion, the NSF SBIR Phase I project not only demonstrated the technical feasibility of the PLEX but also laid the groundwork for its further development and commercialization. The achievements of this project have the potential to revolutionize energy recovery practices in multiple industrial sectors, making a significant contribution towards sustainable industrial process transition. As the project proceeds to Phase II, the focus will shift towards commercialization and broadening the application of the technology to maximize its impact on energy-efficient practices.
